titlePart.supplied: Birth Control Clinics and the Depression

sourceDesc.bibl: Birth Control Clinic Taxed by Depression, The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, 28 Dec 1930, p. 6

docBody.head: Birth Control Clinic Taxed by Depression

p.q: Birth Control derives new significance as a result of the change in economic conditions, in the opinion of Margaret Sanger, director of the Clinical Research Bureau. She declares that the number of patients at the clinic,whose husbands are among the jobless, has increased 65 percent during the last few months.

docBody.p: "We find particularly an increased number of women patients among the very poor classes," Mrs. Sanger says,"while the number of our regular patients steadily increases. We are handling from 1,500 to 1,800 cases a month at present and are running steadily three weeks behind in taking care of appointments."

"I feel that this entire unsettled economic condition is definitely tied up with over population," Mrs. Sanger asserts, "and I am particularly pleased to see our work increasing at this time. Within the last 20 years we have displaced thousands of men with machines. The result is that we have an overproduction of population."

div.head: Need Lower Birth Rate
div.p: "We could very easily do with a tremendous reduction of the birth rate in this country, as well as a further restriction of immigration during the next 10 years. In that time, we could absorb the present population, which is glutting the labor market today."

"I feel that both national and international welfare are bound up in the population problem. A nation with surplus man-power is one suffering with economic depression and restlessness. One cannot forget the assertion of the veterans that they would rather be in the trenches than in the breadlines."

p.q: Mrs. Sanger thinks religious opposition to her work is decreasing, and that women of all faiths are about equality represented among the patients at the clinic.

div.p: "There has been a change of attitude, too, on the part of the average woman toward our work," she says. "Women of all classes now come to the bureau for advice."

p.q: As head of the National Committee on Federal Legislation for Birth Control, Mrs. Sanger predicts that the efforts to get a repeal of the Comstock laws, which prohibit the sending of contraceptive information through the mails, will be renewed in the next session of Congress.

div.head: Fights for Principles
div.p: "I am fighting for the repeal of those laws partly because of the principles involved and partially because of their potentialities," she said. "As things stand now, doctors can get birth control to be bootlegged, and that is not self-respecting. I shall protest against the Federal laws in Congress, on the ground that they interfere with the rights of individuals."

" Every physician at some time needs to have birth control information, to pass it on to his patients, but unless he gets that information in his medical school-- and that is very rare- he has no means under the present laws of procuring it other than by bootlegging methods, The booting methods may be followed, or we may repeal the law, come out in the open and go along intelligently with science. I prefer the latter method, and I believe economic conditions such as we are facing now emphasize the necessity for these doctrines."

div.head: Old Feud Smoulders

p.q: The controversy between the National Committee on Federal Legislation for Birth Control , headed by Mrs. Sanger, and the American birth Control League, headed by Mrs. F. Robertson Jones, which broke out last year over questions of policy, is still smouldering, Mrs. Sanger said.

div.p: The league, through its president, has repudiated the work of the national committee, asserting that "contrary to the prevalent understanding, the Federal law does not actually interfere with our program, as it leaves physicians free to give contraceptive advice orally both in their private practice and in their clinics."

p.q: Commenting on the league's position, Mrs. Sanger said:

div.p: "They forget that unless physicians can get reliable information themselves, they cannot give it to their patients."
"The Federal laws most decidedly interfere with the getting and giving of information by physicians and, as long as they exist, our work is hampered."

"I am not discouraged by this controversy between myself and the league, however. Our work has been like a growing cell. It gt to a certain point as a unit, and then it divided. We are still the same body, however."
